[![Godavari
River.png](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Godavari_River.png/300px-
Godavari_River.png)](/wiki/File:Godavari_River.png)Path of the Godavari

The **Godavari** is [India](/wiki/India "India")'s second longest river after
the [Ganga](/wiki/Ganges_river "Ganges river"). Its source is in
Triambakeshwar, [Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra").[4] It flows
east for 1,465 kilometres (910 mi) draining the states of Maharashtra (48.6%),
[Telangana](/wiki/Telangana "Telangana") (18.8%), [Andhra
Pradesh](/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh "Andhra Pradesh") (4.5%),
[Chhattisgarh](/wiki/Chhattisgarh "Chhattisgarh") (10.9%), [Madhya
Pradesh](/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh "Madhya Pradesh") (10.0%), [Odisha](/wiki/Odisha
"Odisha") (5.7%), [Karnataka](/wiki/Karnataka "Karnataka") (1.4%) and
[Puducherry](/wiki/Puducherry "Puducherry") ([Yanam](/wiki/Yanam_district
"Yanam district")) and emptying into [Bay of Bengal](/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal "Bay
of Bengal") through its extensive network of tributaries.[5] Measuring up to
312,812 km2 (120,777 sq mi), it forms one of the largest [river
basins](/wiki/River_basin "River basin") in the [Indian
subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian subcontinent"), with only the
Ganges and [Indus](/wiki/Indus "Indus") rivers having a larger drainage
basin.[6] In terms of length, catchment area and discharge, the Godavari river
is the largest in peninsular India, and had been dubbed as the **Dakshina
Ganga** – Ganges of the South.[7]

The river has been revered in Hindu scriptures for many millennia and
continues to harbour and nourish a rich cultural heritage. In the past few
decades, the river has been barricaded by a number of
[barrages](/wiki/Barrage_\(dam\) "Barrage \(dam\)") and [dams](/wiki/Dams
"Dams"), restricting its flow. The [river delta](/wiki/River_delta "River
delta") supports 729 persons/km2 – nearly twice the density average for the
nation, and has been categorized as having substantial to greater risk of
flooding with rising sea levels.[8][9]

## Source[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Godavari_River&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Source")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Godavari-

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Godavari_satellite_view.jpg/220px-
Godavari_satellite_view.jpg)](/wiki/File:Godavari_satellite_view.jpg)

Godavari River delta extending into the [Bay of Bengal](/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal
"Bay of Bengal") (upper river in image).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Bhadrachalam_during_2005_floods.jpg/250px-
Bhadrachalam_during_2005_floods.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bhadrachalam_during_2005_floods.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bhadrachalam_during_2005_floods.jpg "Enlarge")

[Bhadrachalam](/wiki/Bhadrachalam "Bhadrachalam") Temple during 2005

The Godavari originates in the [Western Ghats](/wiki/Western_Ghats "Western
Ghats") of central India near [Nashik](/wiki/Nashik "Nashik") in
[Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra"), 80 km (50 mi) from the
[Arabian Sea](/wiki/Arabian_Sea "Arabian Sea"). It flows for 1,465 km (910
mi), first eastwards across the [Deccan Plateau](/wiki/Deccan_Plateau "Deccan
Plateau") then turns southeast, entering the [West Godavari
district](/wiki/West_Godavari_district "West Godavari district") and [East
Godavari district](/wiki/East_Godavari_district "East Godavari district") of
Andhra Pradesh, until it splits into two distributaries that widen into a
large [river delta](/wiki/River_delta "River delta") and flow into the Bay of
Bengal.[11]

The Godavari River has a coverage area of 312,812 km2 (120,777 sq mi), which
is nearly one-tenth of the area of India and is greater than the areas of
[England](/wiki/England "England") and [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland") put
together. The river basin is considered to be divided into 3 sections:

  * Upper (source to confluence with [Manjira](/wiki/Manjira_River "Manjira River")),
  * Middle (between confluence of [Manjira](/wiki/Manjira_River "Manjira River") and [Pranhita](/wiki/Pranhita "Pranhita")) and
  * Lower ([Pranhita](/wiki/Pranhita "Pranhita") confluence to mouth).

These put together account for 24.2% of the total basin area.[12] The rivers
annual average water inflows are nearly 110 billion cubic metres.[13] Nearly
50% of the water availability is being harnessed. The water allocation from
the river among the riparian states are governed by the [Godavari Water
Disputes Tribunal](/wiki/Godavari_Water_Disputes_Tribunal "Godavari Water
Disputes Tribunal"). The river has highest flood flows in India and
experienced recorded flood of 3.6 million
[cusecs](/wiki/Cubic_foot#Cubic_foot_per_second "Cubic foot") in the year 1986
and annual flood of 1.0 million cusecs is normal.[14][15]

### Within
Maharashtra[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Godavari_River&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Within Maharashtra")]

In [Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra") state where it takes origin,
the river has an extensive course, the upper basin (origin to its confluence
with [Manjira](/wiki/Manjira_River "Manjira River")) of which lies entirely
within the state, cumulatively draining an area as large as 152,199 km2
(58,764 sq mi) – about half the area of [Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra
"Maharashtra").[16] Within [Nashik District](/wiki/Nashik_District "Nashik
District") the river assumes a north-easterly course till it flows into the
[Gangapur Reservoir](/wiki/Gangapur_Dam "Gangapur Dam") created by a dam of
the same name. The reservoir along with the [Kashypi Dam](/wiki/Kashypi_Dam
"Kashypi Dam") provides potable water to Nashik, one of the largest cities
located on its banks. The river as it emerges through the dam, some 8 km (5.0
mi) upstream from Nashik, flows on a rocky bed undulated by a series of chasms
and rocky ledges, resulting in the formation of two significant waterfalls –
the Gangapur waterfalls and the Someshwar Waterfalls, the latter, located at
Someshwar and more popularly known as the Dudhsagar Waterfall[17] About 10 km
(6.2 mi) east of Gangapur the river passes the town of [Nashik](/wiki/Nashik
"Nashik") where it collects its effluents in the form of the river Nasardi on
its right bank.

About 0.5 km (0.31 mi) south direction from Nashik, the river bends sharply to
the east, washing the base of a high cliff formerly the site of a Mughal fort,
but which is now being eaten away by the action of floods. About 25 km (16 mi)
below Nashik is the confluence of the Godavari and one of its tributaries, the
[Darna river](/wiki/Darna_River "Darna River"). The stream occupies, for nine
months in the year, a small space in a wide and gravelly bed, the greyish
banks being 4 to 6 m (13 to 20 ft) high, topped with a deep layer of black
soil. A few kilometres after its meeting with the Darna, the Godavari swerves
to the north-east, till the [Banganga](/wiki/Banganga_River_\(Maharashtra\)
"Banganga River \(Maharashtra\)"), from the north-west, meets it on the left.
The course of the main stream then tends more decidedly south. At Nandur-
Madhmeshwar, the [Kadva](/wiki/Kadva_River "Kadva River"), a second large
affluent, brings considerable increase to the waters of the Godavari. The
river begins its southeasterly course characteristic of rivers of the [Deccan
Plateau](/wiki/Deccan_Plateau "Deccan Plateau"). The river beyond exits the
[Niphad](/wiki/Niphad "Niphad") Taluka of [Nashik](/wiki/Nashik "Nashik") and
enter the [Kopargaon taluka](/wiki/Kopargaon_taluka "Kopargaon taluka"),
[Ahmednagar District](/wiki/Ahmednagar_district "Ahmednagar district"). Within
[Ahmednagar](/wiki/Ahmednagar_district "Ahmednagar district") the river
quickly completes its short course, flowing alongside the town of
[Kopargaon](/wiki/Kopargaon "Kopargaon") and reaching Puntamba. Beyond this
the river has been deployed as a natural boundary between the following
districts :

  * [Ahmednagar](/wiki/Ahmednagar_district "Ahmednagar district") and [Aurangabad](/wiki/Aurangabad_District,_Maharashtra "Aurangabad District, Maharashtra"): Along the boundary here, it receives its first major tributary [Pravara River](/wiki/Pravara_River "Pravara River"), draining the former district, the confluence located at Pravarasangam. By virtue of a sub-tributary of Pravara – Mandohol, which originates in Pune District – the basin impinges the [Pune District](/wiki/Pune_District "Pune District"). The river at Paithan has been impounded by the [Jayakwadi Dam](/wiki/Jayakwadi_Dam "Jayakwadi Dam") forming the NathSagar Reservoir. [Kalsubai](/wiki/Kalsubai "Kalsubai") located in Godavari basin, is the highest peak in Maharashtra.
  * [Beed](/wiki/Beed_District "Beed District") and [Jalna](/wiki/Jalna_District "Jalna District")
  * [Beed](/wiki/Beed_District "Beed District") and [Parbhani](/wiki/Parbhani_District "Parbhani District"): Located along here is its merger with [Sindphana](/wiki/Sindphana_River "Sindphana River"), an important tributary[18] which drains a considerably large area within [Beed](/wiki/Beed_District "Beed District"). The sub-tributary river [Bindusara](/wiki/Bindusara_River "Bindusara River") forms a landmark at [Beed](/wiki/Beed "Beed").

The river beyond, near the village Sonpeth, flows into
[Parbhani](/wiki/Parbhani_District "Parbhani District"). Its course is
relatively non-significant except for receiving two smaller streams –
Indrayani and Masuli – merging at its left and right banks respectively.
Within the last taluka of the district [Parbhani](/wiki/Parbhani_District
"Parbhani District"), [Purna](/wiki/Purna "Purna"), the river drains a major
tributary of the same name:
[Purna](/wiki/Purna_River_\(tributary_of_Godavari\) "Purna River \(tributary
of Godavari\)")[19]

It then exits into the neighboring district of [Nanded](/wiki/Nanded_District
"Nanded District") where 10 km (6.2 mi) before reaching the town Nanded, is
impounded by the Vishnupuri Dam and thus with it, bringing Asia's largest lift
irrigation projects to life. A little downstream from Nanded, the river
receives Asna, a small stream, on its left bank.It then runs into the
controversial [Babli project](/wiki/Babli_project "Babli project") soon ends
its course within [Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra"), albeit
temporarily, at its merger with a major tributary –
[Manjira](/wiki/Manjira_River "Manjira River").

The river after flowing into Telangana, re-emerges to run as a state boundary
separating the [Mancherial](/wiki/Mancherial_district "Mancherial district"),
[Telangana](/wiki/Telangana "Telangana") from
[Gadchiroli](/wiki/Gadchiroli_district "Gadchiroli district"), Maharashtra. At
the state border, it runs between [Sironcha](/wiki/Sironcha "Sironcha") and
Somnoor Sangam receiving one tributary at each of those nodal points – the
[Pranhita](/wiki/Pranhita_River "Pranhita River") and subsequently the
[Indravati](/wiki/Indravati_River "Indravati River").

### Within
Telangana[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Godavari_River&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Within Telangana")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Road_Bridge_over_Godavari_River_at_Bhadrachalam.JPG/300px-
Road_Bridge_over_Godavari_River_at_Bhadrachalam.JPG)](/wiki/File:Road_Bridge_over_Godavari_River_at_Bhadrachalam.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Road_Bridge_over_Godavari_River_at_Bhadrachalam.JPG "Enlarge")

Road Bridge over Godavari River at Bhadrachalam

Godavari enters into Telangana in Nizamabad district at Kandakurthy where
Manjira, Haridra rivers joins Godavari and forms Triveni Sangamam. The river
flows along the border between [Nirmal](/wiki/Nirmal_district "Nirmal
district") and [Mancherial districts](/wiki/Mancherial_district "Mancherial
district") in the north and [Nizamabad](/wiki/Nizamabad_district "Nizamabad
district"), [Jagityal](/wiki/Jagtial_district "Jagtial district"),
[Peddapalli](/wiki/Peddapalli_district "Peddapalli district") districts to its
south. About 12 km (7.5 mi) after entering [Telangana](/wiki/Telangana
"Telangana") it merges with the back waters of the [Sriram Sagar
Dam](/wiki/Sriram_Sagar_Project "Sriram Sagar Project"). The river after
emerging through the dam gates, enjoys a wide river bed, often splitting to
encase sandy islands. The river receives a minor but significant tributary
[Kadam river](/wiki/Kadam_river "Kadam river"). It then emerges at its eastern
side to act as state border with Maharashtra only to later enter into
[Bhadradri Kothagudem district](/wiki/Bhadradri_Kothagudem_district "Bhadradri
Kothagudem district"). In this district the river flows through an important
Hindu pilgrimage town – [Bhadrachalam](/wiki/Bhadrachalam "Bhadrachalam").

The river further swells after receiving a minor tributary [Kinnerasani
River](/wiki/Kinnerasani_River "Kinnerasani River") and exits into [Andhra
Pradesh](/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh "Andhra Pradesh").

### Within Andhra
Pradesh[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Godavari_River&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Within Andhra Pradesh")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Early_morning_in_Godavari_02.jpg/220px-
Early_morning_in_Godavari_02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Early_morning_in_Godavari_02.jpg)

The river at [Papi Hills](/wiki/Papi_Hills "Papi Hills") in [Andhra
Pradesh](/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh "Andhra Pradesh").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e5/Yanam_Godavari.jpg/220px-
Yanam_Godavari.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yanam_Godavari.jpg)

The river near Yanam.

Within the state of [Andhra Pradesh](/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh "Andhra Pradesh"),
it flows through hilly terrain of the [Eastern Ghats](/wiki/Eastern_Ghats
"Eastern Ghats") known as the [Papi hills](/wiki/Papi_Hills "Papi Hills")
which explains the narrowing of its bed as it flows through a gorge for a few
km, only to re-widen at [Polavaram](/wiki/Polavaram "Polavaram"). Before
crossing the Papi hills, it receives its last major tributary [Sabari
River](/wiki/Sabari_River "Sabari River") on its left bank. The river upon
reaching the plains begins to widen out until it reaches
[Rajamundry](/wiki/Rajamundry "Rajamundry"). [Arma Konda](/wiki/Arma_Konda
"Arma Konda") or Jindhagada Peak (1,680 m (5,510 ft) above
[msl](/wiki/Mean_sea_level "Mean sea level")) located near
[Paderu](/wiki/Paderu "Paderu") is the highest peak in the Godavari river
basin as well as in Eastern Ghats.[20][21]

After crossing [Rajahmundry](/wiki/Rajahmundry "Rajahmundry"), the Godavari
splits into two branches which are called Vriddha Gautami (Gautami Godavari)
and Vasishta Godavari. Again the Gautami branch splits into two branches
namely Gautami and Nilarevu. Similarly the Vasishta splits into two branches
named Vasishta and Vainateya. These four branches which join the [Bay of
Bengal](/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal "Bay of Bengal") at different places, are forming
a delta of length 170 km (110 mi) along the coast of the Bay of Bengal and is
called the [Konaseema](/wiki/Konaseema "Konaseema") region. This delta along
with the delta of the [Krishna River](/wiki/Krishna_River "Krishna River") is
called the _Rice Granary_ of [South India](/wiki/South_India "South
India").[22]

## Tributaries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Godavari_River&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Tributaries")]

The major [tributaries](/wiki/Tributary "Tributary") of the river can be
classified[23] as the left bank tributaries which include the
[Purna](/wiki/Purna_River_\(tributary_of_Godavari\) "Purna River \(tributary
of Godavari\)"), [Pranhita](/wiki/Pranhita "Pranhita"),
[Indravati](/wiki/Indravati "Indravati") and [Sabari River](/wiki/Sabari_River
"Sabari River") covering nearly 59.7% of the total catchment area of the basin
and the right bank tributaries [Pravara](/wiki/Pravara_River "Pravara River"),
[Manjira](/wiki/Manjira_River "Manjira River"), [Manair](/wiki/Manair_River
"Manair River") together contributing 16.1% of the basin.

[Pranhita](/wiki/Pranhita "Pranhita") is the largest tributary covering about
34% of its drainage basin. Though the river proper flows only for 113 km (70
mi), by virtue of its extensive tributaries [Wardha](/wiki/Wardha_River
"Wardha River"), [Wainganga](/wiki/Wainganga "Wainganga"),
[Penganga](/wiki/Painganga_River "Painganga River"), the sub-basin drains all
of [Vidharba](/wiki/Vidharba "Vidharba") region as well as the southern slopes
of the [Satpura Ranges](/wiki/Satpura_Range "Satpura Range").
[Indravati](/wiki/Indravati "Indravati") is the 2nd largest tributary, known
as the "lifeline" of the [Kalahandi](/wiki/Kalahandi "Kalahandi"),
[Nabarangapur](/wiki/Nabarangapur "Nabarangapur") of [Odisha](/wiki/Odisha
"Odisha") & [Bastar district](/wiki/Bastar_district "Bastar district") of
[Chhattisgarh](/wiki/Chhattisgarh "Chhattisgarh"). Due to their enormous sub-
basins both [Indravati](/wiki/Indravati "Indravati") and
[Pranhita](/wiki/Pranhita "Pranhita") are considered rivers in their own
right. [Manjira](/wiki/Manjira "Manjira") is the longest tributary and holds
the [Nizam Sagar](/wiki/Nizam_Sagar "Nizam Sagar") reservoir.
[Purna](/wiki/Purna_River_\(tributary_of_Godavari\) "Purna River \(tributary
of Godavari\)") is a prime river in the water scarce
[Marathwada](/wiki/Marathwada "Marathwada") region of
[Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra").

[Pravara](/wiki/Pravara_River "Pravara River") | Right | Pravara Sangam, [Nevasa](/wiki/Nevasa_taluka "Nevasa taluka"), [Ahmednagar](/wiki/Ahmednagar_District "Ahmednagar District"), [Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra") | 463 m (1,519 ft) | 208 km (129 mi) | 6,537 km2 (2,524 sq mi)   
[Purna](/wiki/Purna_River_\(tributary_of_Godavari\) "Purna River \(tributary of Godavari\)") | Left | Jambulbet, [Parbhani](/wiki/Parbhani_District "Parbhani District"), [Marathwada](/wiki/Marathwada "Marathwada"), [Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra") | 358 m (1,175 ft) | 373 km (232 mi) | 15,579 km2 (6,015 sq mi)   
[Manjira](/wiki/Manjira_River "Manjira River") | Right | Kandakurthi, Renjal, [Nizamabad, Telangana](/wiki/Nizamabad,_Telangana "Nizamabad, Telangana") | 332 m (1,089 ft) | 724 km (450 mi) | 30,844 km2 (11,909 sq mi)   
[Manair](/wiki/Manair_River "Manair River") | Right | Arenda, [Manthani](/wiki/Manthani "Manthani"), [Karimnagar](/wiki/Karimnagar "Karimnagar"), [Telangana](/wiki/Telangana "Telangana") | 115 m (377 ft) | 225 km (140 mi) | 13,106 km2 (5,060 sq mi)   
[Pranhita](/wiki/Pranhita "Pranhita") | Left | Kaleshwaram, [Mahadevpur](/wiki/Mahadevpur "Mahadevpur"), [Karimnagar](/wiki/Karimnagar "Karimnagar"), [Telangana](/wiki/Telangana "Telangana") | 99 m (325 ft) | 113 km (70 mi) | 109,078 km2 (42,115 sq mi)   
[Indravati](/wiki/Indravati "Indravati") | Left | Somnoor Sangam, [Sironcha](/wiki/Sironcha "Sironcha"), [Gadchiroli](/wiki/Gadchiroli_District "Gadchiroli District"), [Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra") | 82 m (269 ft) | 535 km (332 mi) | 41,655 km2 (16,083 sq mi)   
[Sabari](/wiki/Sabari_River "Sabari River") | Left | Kunawaram, [East Godavari](/wiki/East_Godavari_District "East Godavari District"), [Andhra Pradesh](/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh "Andhra Pradesh") | 25 m (82 ft) | 418 km (260 mi) | 20,427 km2 (7,887 sq mi)   
  
Other than these 7 principal ones, it has many smaller but significant ones
draining into it.

Goddess Godavari

The river is sacred to [Hindus](/wiki/Hindus "Hindus") and has several places
on its banks, that have been places of pilgrimage for thousands of years.
Amongst the huge numbers of people who have bathed in her waters as a rite of
cleansing are said to have been the deity [Baladeva](/wiki/Balarama
"Balarama") 5000 years ago and the saint [Chaitanya
Mahaprabhu](/wiki/Chaitanya_Mahaprabhu "Chaitanya Mahaprabhu") 500 years ago.
Every twelve years, [Pushkaram](/wiki/Godavari_Maha_Pushkaram "Godavari Maha
Pushkaram") fair is held on the banks of the river.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Sculpture_depicting_govu_vatsa_and_gowthama_legend.jpg/220px-
Sculpture_depicting_govu_vatsa_and_gowthama_legend.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sculpture_depicting_govu_vatsa_and_gowthama_legend.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sculpture_depicting_govu_vatsa_and_gowthama_legend.jpg
"Enlarge")

Sculpture depicting govu vatsa and gowthama legend about birth of Godavari
River

A legend has it that the sage Gautama lived in the Brahmagiri Hills at
[Tryambakeshwar](/wiki/Tryambakeshwar "Tryambakeshwar") with his wife Ahalya.
The couple lived the rest of their lives in the then village called _Govuru_ ,
known as [Kovvur](/wiki/Kovvur "Kovvur") ("cow") since the British rule.
Ahalya lived in a nearby place called _Thagami_ (now [Thogummi](/wiki/Thogummi
"Thogummi")). The sage, as a reason for the practice of _annadanam_ ("giving
away food" to the needy), started cultivating rice crops and other crops.
Once, the god [Ganesha](/wiki/Ganesha "Ganesha"), on the wish of the
[munis](/wiki/Rishi_Muni "Rishi Muni"), sent a miraculous cow _maaya-dhenu_ ,
which resembled a normal cow. It entered the sage's abode and started spoiling
the rice while he was meditating. Since cattle is sacred to Hindus and shall
always be treated with respect, he put the _dharbha_ grass on the cow. But, to
his surprise, it fell dead. Seeing what happened before their eyes, the munis
and their wives cried out, "We thought that Gautama-maharishi is a righteous
man, but he committed bovicide (killing of a cow or cattle)!". The sage wished
to atone for this grievous sin. Therefore, he went to [Nashik](/wiki/Nashik
"Nashik") and observed [tapas](/wiki/Tapas_\(Sanskrit\) "Tapas \(Sanskrit\)")
to Lord Tryambakeshwara (a manifestation of the god [Shiva](/wiki/Shiva
"Shiva")), on the advice of the munis, praying for atonement and asking Him to
make the [Ganges](/wiki/Ganges "Ganges") flow over the cow. Shiva was pleased
with the sage and diverted the Ganges which washed away the cow and gave rise
to the Godavari river in Nashik. The water stream flowed past Kovvur and
ultimately merged with the Bay of Bengal.

### Places of
interest[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Godavari_River&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Places of interest")]

Sites of pilgrimage include:

  * [Basar](/wiki/Basar,_Andhra_Pradesh "Basar, Andhra Pradesh") (originally, Vyasara) – Sri Gyana [Saraswati](/wiki/Saraswati "Saraswati") temple is situated on the banks of Godavari in Adilabad district, Telangana. It is about 210 km (130 mi) from state capital Hyderabad and accessible by road and rail (nearest major station: Nizamabad, although Basar station also exists). It is considered that the sage Vyasa wrote the Mahabharata on the banks of Godavari at this location near Harsha house it is the beautiful scenario, and thus the place came to be known as Vyasara.
  * [Kandhakurthi](/w/index.php?title=Kandhakurthi&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kandhakurthi \(page does not exist\)") \- Thriveni sangamam where three rivers join. Godavari, [Manjira River](/wiki/Manjira_River "Manjira River") and [Haridra River](/w/index.php?title=Haridra_River&action=edit&redlink=1 "Haridra River \(page does not exist\)").
  * [Bhadrachalam](/wiki/Bhadrachalam "Bhadrachalam") – Hindu Temple of [Lord Rama](/wiki/Rama "Rama").
  * [Dharmapuri, Telangana](/wiki/Dharmapuri,_Telangana "Dharmapuri, Telangana") – Hindu Temple of Lord [Narasimha](/wiki/Narasimha_Swamy "Narasimha Swamy"). Godavari flows from north to south in Dharmapuri, hence the river is locally called 'Dakshina Vahini' [South Flowing]
  * [Kaleshwaram](/wiki/Kaleshwaram "Kaleshwaram") – Sri Kaleswara Mukhteswara swamy Temple is situated here on the banks of Triveni sangamam of rivers godavari and pranahita. It is 125 kilometres away from Karimnagar city, 115 km away from Warangal city.
  * [Trimbakeshwar](/wiki/Trimbakeshwar "Trimbakeshwar") – One of the twelve [Jyotirlingas](/wiki/Jyotirlinga "Jyotirlinga") and ancient temple of [Lord Shiva](/wiki/Lord_Shiva "Lord Shiva").
  * [Nanded](/wiki/Nanded "Nanded") – [Takht Sri Hazur Sahib](/wiki/Takht_Sri_Hazur_Sahib "Takht Sri Hazur Sahib"), one of the five most sacred places in [Sikhism](/wiki/Sikhism "Sikhism").
  * [Nashik](/wiki/Nashik "Nashik") – One of the four [Sinhastha Kumbh Mela](/wiki/Kumbh_Mela "Kumbh Mela"), Hindu pilgrimage place.
  * [Paithan](/wiki/Paithan "Paithan") – Saint Eknath's native place, famous [Jayakwadi dam](/wiki/Jayakwadi_dam "Jayakwadi dam"), and a beautiful garden named after Sant [Dnyneshwar](/w/index.php?title=Dnyneshwar&action=edit&redlink=1 "Dnyneshwar \(page does not exist\)").

  * [Antarvedi](/wiki/Antarvedi "Antarvedi"), East Godavari (Antarvedi is famous for the Laxmi Narasimha Swamy temple constructed between the 15th and 16th centuries. There is also a temple of Lord Siva that is older than Narasimha Swamy temple. The temple's idol of Lord Siva was installed by Lord Srirama.
  * [Konaseema](/wiki/Konaseema "Konaseema") – Delta of Godavari.
  * [Pattiseema](/wiki/Pattiseema "Pattiseema") – A village where a [Hindu](/wiki/Hindu "Hindu") temple is located on a small hill on an island in the river.
  * [Kovvur](/wiki/Kovvur "Kovvur") – A village where cows resided and a place where the maaya-dhenu fell dead. Footprints of the maaya-dhenu were seen even today in the famous place Kovvur called "Goshpadakshetram" also called "Gopadala Revu" where the footprints of the holy cow are seen near the temple of Lord Shiva. Also a village which is the reason for the birth of river [Godavari](/wiki/Godavari "Godavari"). Famous for a Sanskrit school which has been built 63 years back.
  * [Rajahmundry](/wiki/Rajahmundry "Rajahmundry") – A town known for its role in Telugu culture and birthplace of writers such as [Nannaya](/wiki/Nannaya "Nannaya"), one of the [Kavitrayam](/wiki/Kavitrayam "Kavitrayam") trinity of poets who translated the [Mahabharata](/wiki/Mahabharata "Mahabharata") into Telugu. The Godavari Pushkaralu is a major local festival that is staged every 12 years.
  * [Araku Valley](/wiki/Araku_Valley "Araku Valley") which is a popular hill station in [Vishakhapatnam District](/wiki/Vishakhapatnam_District "Vishakhapatnam District").
  * [Lambasingi](/wiki/Lambasingi "Lambasingi") hill station known for snowfall during winter season in Vishakhapatnam district.
  * [Deomali peak](/wiki/Deomali_\(mountain\) "Deomali \(mountain\)") located in the Godavari basin is the highest peak (1672 m [msl](/wiki/Mean_sea_level "Mean sea level")) in Odisha state.
  * Mandasa village in Srikakulam district- famous for Sri Vasudev Perumal temple, famous for sweet "kova", near mahendragiri hill (highest peak in eastern ghats).

## Flora and
fauna[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Godavari_River&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Flora and fauna")]

See also: [Wildlife sanctuaries of India](/wiki/Wildlife_sanctuaries_of_India
"Wildlife sanctuaries of India"), [Tiger reserves of
India](/wiki/Tiger_reserves_of_India "Tiger reserves of India"), and [List of
national parks of India](/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_India "List of
national parks of India")

  * The [Krishna Godavari Basin](/wiki/Krishna_Godavari_Basin "Krishna Godavari Basin") is one of the main nesting sites of the endangered [Olive Ridley sea turtle](/wiki/Olive_Ridley_sea_turtle "Olive Ridley sea turtle"). Godavari is also a home to the endangered fringed-lipped carp ([Labeo fimbriatus](/wiki/Labeo_fimbriatus "Labeo fimbriatus")).[25]
  * The [Coringa mangrove forests](/wiki/Coringa_Wildlife_Sanctuary "Coringa Wildlife Sanctuary") in the Godavari delta are the second largest mangrove formation in the country. Part of this has been declared as the [Coringa Wildlife Sanctuary](/wiki/Coringa_Wildlife_Sanctuary "Coringa Wildlife Sanctuary"), renowned for reptiles. They also provide an important habitat to a wide variety of fish and crustaceans. These forests also act as barriers against cyclones, tropical storms, and [storm surges](/wiki/Storm_surge "Storm surge"), thus protecting the nearby villages.
  * The [Jayakwadi Bird Sanctuary](/wiki/Jayakwadi_Dam#Jayakwadi_Bird_Sanctuary "Jayakwadi Dam") is another haven for birds located near the town of Paithan spread across the back waters of the NathSagar Reservoir formed by impounding the Godavari by the massive [Jayakwadi Dam](/wiki/Jayakwadi_Dam "Jayakwadi Dam"). Its 341 km2 area is dotted by islands within the reservoir which serve as nesting sites for the birds.[26]
  * The Nandurmadmeshwar Bird Sanctuary is located along the back waters of the Godavari river near [Nashik](/wiki/Nashik "Nashik") at its confluence with [Kadva River](/wiki/Kadva_River "Kadva River").[27] It is known as the Bharatpur of Maharashtra for the wide diversity of bird life that it harbours.

## Crossings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Godavari_River&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Crossings")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Godavari_Bridge.jpg/220px-
Godavari_Bridge.jpg)](/wiki/File:Godavari_Bridge.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Godavari_Bridge.jpg "Enlarge")

[Havelock Bridge](/wiki/Havelock_Bridge "Havelock Bridge") on the left and
[Godavari Arch Bridge](/wiki/Godavari_Arch_Bridge "Godavari Arch Bridge") on
the right

There are 4 bridges spanning the river between [East
Godavari](/wiki/East_Godavari "East Godavari") and [West
Godavari](/wiki/West_Godavari "West Godavari") districts.

  1. [Old Godavari Bridge](/wiki/Old_Godavari_Bridge "Old Godavari Bridge") (also known as Havelock bridge, and named after then Madras governor)
  2. [Godavari Bridge](/wiki/Godavari_Bridge "Godavari Bridge") (also known as Rail-cum-road bridge and Kovvur-Rajahmundry Bridge)
  3. [Godavari Arch Bridge](/wiki/Godavari_Arch_Bridge "Godavari Arch Bridge") (also known as New railway bridge)
  4. Fourth Bridge (also known as new road bridge)

  * Old Godavari Bridge

Construction of this bridge started in 1876, and was completed in 1897. It was
constructed under the supervision of F.T. Granville Walton who had constructed
the Dufferin Bridge over the Ganges, and Granville Mills, both British
engineers. Spanning over 3 km in length, it linked the East Godavari and West
Godavari districts. The bridge has been a vital link enabling trains to run
between [Chennai](/wiki/Chennai "Chennai") and [Howrah](/wiki/Howrah
"Howrah"). Trains continued over the bridge for a century until 1997, when
train services over the bridge were suspended after the construction of two
additional bridges.

  * Godavari Bridge

Construction of this bridge started in 1970, and was completed in 1974. It
serves as both a railway and a roadway between the East Godavari and West
Godavari Districts.

  * Godavari Arch Bridge

This bridge was completed in 1997, was built upstream of the earlier bridges.

  * Fourth Bridge

This bridge is the newest. It was opened to public from Godavari Pushkaras
2015. This is a road connectivity bridge link supposed to ease traffic flow
between Rajamundry and Kovvur

## Dams[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Godavari_River&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Dams")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Jayakwadi_Dam.jpg/220px-
Jayakwadi_Dam.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jayakwadi_Dam.jpg)

An upstream view of Jayakwadi Dam.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Sri_Ram_Sagar_Project_%28Pochampahad%29.jpg/220px-
Sri_Ram_Sagar_Project_%28Pochampahad%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sri_Ram_Sagar_Project_\(Pochampahad\).jpg)

[Sriram Sagar Dam](/wiki/Sriram_Sagar_Project "Sriram Sagar Project").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Dowleswaram_Barrage.jpg/220px-
Dowleswaram_Barrage.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dowleswaram_Barrage.jpg)

Dowleswaram Dam near Rajahmundry on the river.

The main Godavari River up to the confluence with Pranhita tributary is dammed
fully to utilize the available water for irrigation. However, its main
tributaries Pranhita, Indravati and Sabari which join in the lower reaches of
the basin, carry three times more water compared to main Godavari.[28] In
2015, the water surplus Godavari River is linked to the water deficit [Krishna
River](/wiki/Krishna_River "Krishna River") by commissioning the [Polavaram
right bank canal](/wiki/Polavaram_Project "Polavaram Project") with the help
of Pattiseema lift scheme to augment water availability to the [Prakasam
Barrage](/wiki/Prakasam_Barrage "Prakasam Barrage") located in Andhra Pradesh.
More dams are constructed in the Godavari River basin than in any other river
basin of India.[29] The following are the few dams located in the river basin:

  * [Gangapur Dam](/wiki/Gangapur_Dam "Gangapur Dam") : This is a large earth fill dam with gross water storage of 215.88 million cubic metres,[30] and located 10 km (6.2 mi) upstream from [Nashik](/wiki/Nashik "Nashik") city. The reservoir known as the Gangapur Bandh Sagar provides drinking water to the Nashik city and also supplies water to the thermal power station situated downstream at [Eklahare](/wiki/Eklahare "Eklahare").
  * [Jayakwadi dam](/wiki/Jayakwadi_dam "Jayakwadi dam") : Located near [Paithan](/wiki/Paithan "Paithan"), it is one of the largest earthen dams in India. This dam was built to address the dual problems of flooding along the banks, during monsoon months, and that of drought, rest of the year, in the [Marathwada](/wiki/Marathwada "Marathwada") region. Two 'left' and 'right' canals provide the irrigation to fertile land up to [Nanded district](/wiki/Nanded_district "Nanded district"). This dam has contributed to industrial development of [Aurangabad](/wiki/Aurangabad_district,_Maharashtra "Aurangabad district, Maharashtra") and [Jalna](/wiki/Jalna_District "Jalna District"), [Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra").[31] [Majalgaon Dam](/wiki/Majalgaon_Dam "Majalgaon Dam") is also constructed under Jayakwadi stage 2 to expand the irrigation potential further in [Parbhani](/wiki/Parbhani_district "Parbhani district"), [Nanded](/wiki/Nanded_district "Nanded district") and [Beed districts](/wiki/Beed_district "Beed district").
  * Vishnupuri barrage: Asia's Largest Lift Irrigation project, the Vishnupuri Prakalp[32] has been constructed on the river at a distance of 5 km (3.1 mi) from the city Nanded.
  * [Ghatghar Dam](/wiki/Ghatghar_Dam "Ghatghar Dam") was built for hydro power generation by diverting the water of Pravara tributary outside Godavari river basin to a west flowing river which joins Arabian sea.
  * [Upper Vaitarna reservoir](/wiki/Upper_Vaitarana_Dam "Upper Vaitarana Dam") was built across west flowing [Vaitarna](/wiki/Vaitarna "Vaitarna") river merging some part of Godavari river catchment area. Godavari water impounded in this reservoir is diverted outside the river basin for [Mumbai](/wiki/Mumbai "Mumbai") city drinking water supply after generating hydro power.
  * [Sriram Sagar Dam](/wiki/Sriram_Sagar_Project "Sriram Sagar Project") : This is another multipurpose project on the Godavari River on the borders of Adilabad and Nizamabad District. It is near the town of Pochampad, 60 km away from Nizamabad. It has been described by [The Hindu](/wiki/The_Hindu "The Hindu") as a "lifeline for a large part of [Telangana](/wiki/Telangana "Telangana")".[33] It serves the irrigation needs in [Karimnagar](/wiki/Karimnagar "Karimnagar"), [Warangal](/wiki/Warangal "Warangal"), [Adilabad](/wiki/Adilabad "Adilabad"), [Nalgonda](/wiki/Nalgonda "Nalgonda"), and [Khammam](/wiki/Khammam "Khammam") districts and also generates power.
  * [Dowleswaram Barrage](/wiki/Dowleswaram_Barrage "Dowleswaram Barrage") was built by Sir [Arthur Cotton](/wiki/Arthur_Cotton "Arthur Cotton") in 1852. It got damaged in 1987 floods, and rebuilt as a barrage cum roadway soon after and named after him. The roadway connects [Dowleswaram](/wiki/Dowleswaram "Dowleswaram") in East Godavari and [Vijjeswaram](/wiki/Vijjeswaram "Vijjeswaram") in West Godavari. The irrigation canals of this barrage also form part of [National Waterway 4](/wiki/National_Waterway_4 "National Waterway 4").

## Geology and sediment transfer in the Godavari Drainage
Basin[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Godavari_River&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: Geology and sediment transfer in the Godavari Drainage Basin")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Generalized_Geological_Map_of_Godavari_Drainage_Basin.jpg/429px-
Generalized_Geological_Map_of_Godavari_Drainage_Basin.jpg)](/wiki/File:Generalized_Geological_Map_of_Godavari_Drainage_Basin.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Generalized_Geological_Map_of_Godavari_Drainage_Basin.jpg
"Enlarge")

Generalized Geological Map of Godavari Drainage Basin

The primary/initial catchment of the Godavari drainage basin is largely
represented by the basalt of the [Deccan Volcanic Province](/wiki/Deccan_Traps
"Deccan Traps") (~50% of the total basin area). This is followed by the
[Precambrian](/wiki/Precambrian "Precambrian") [granites](/wiki/Granite
"Granite") and [gneisses](/wiki/Gneiss "Gneiss") of the eastern [Dharwar
Craton](/wiki/Dharwar_Craton "Dharwar Craton"), [sandstones](/wiki/Sandstone
"Sandstone"), [shales](/wiki/Shale "Shale") and [limestones](/wiki/Limestone
"Limestone") of the [Gondwana](/wiki/Gondwana "Gondwana") Supergroup, various
sedimentary units of Cuddapah and Vindhyan basins,
[charnockites](/wiki/Charnockite "Charnockite") and
[khondalites](/wiki/Khondalite "Khondalite") of the
[Proterozoic](/wiki/Proterozoic "Proterozoic") [Eastern
Ghats](/wiki/Eastern_Ghats "Eastern Ghats") Mobile Belt and the sandstones of
the Rajahmundry Formation.[36] The Godavari River carries the largest sediment
load among the peninsular rivers and the majority of the mass transfer in
Godavari occurs during the monsoon.[37] Mineral magnetic studies of the
Godavari River sediments suggest that the floodplains in the entire stretch of
the river are characterized by a Deccan basalt source. The bed loads on the
other hand are of sourced from local bedrock. Influx of Deccan source in the
Godavari River up to the delta regions and possibly in the [Bay of
Bengal](/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal "Bay of Bengal") off the Godavari, therefore, can
be related to the intensive [chemical weathering](/wiki/Chemical_weathering
"Chemical weathering") in the Deccan basalts.[38] Abrupt increase in δ13C
values and decrease in TOC content accompanied with a significant increase in
ferrimagnetic mineral concentration in Bay of Bengal sediments from ~3.2 to
3.1 cal. ka BP reflected a shift of organic carbon and sediment source and a
severe decline in vegetation coverage. Such phenomena indicate intensified
deforestation and soil/rock erosion in the Deccan Plateau producing higher
ferrimagnetic mineral inputs, which is in agreement with significant expansion
of agricultural activities in the Deccan Chalcolithic cultural period.[39]

## Ecological
concerns[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Godavari_River&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: Ecological concerns")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/The_Godavari_river_at_Puntamba_in_January.JPG/220px-
The_Godavari_river_at_Puntamba_in_January.JPG)](/wiki/File:The_Godavari_river_at_Puntamba_in_January.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:The_Godavari_river_at_Puntamba_in_January.JPG "Enlarge")

Dried up Godavari exposing [flood basalt](/wiki/Flood_basalt "Flood basalt")
river bed as seen from the back of Changdev temple in
[Puntamba](/wiki/Puntamba "Puntamba")

The frequent drying up of the Godavari river in the drier months has been a
matter of great concern. Indiscriminate damming along the river has been cited
as an obvious reason. Within Maharashtra sugarcane irrigation has been blamed
as one of the foremost causes.[40]

In 2013, the river was at its all-time low in the [Nizamabad
district](/wiki/Nizamabad_district "Nizamabad district") of Telangana. This
had hit the growth of fish, making the life of fishermen miserable.The water-
level was so low that people could easily walk into the middle of the river.
Shortage in rainfall and closure of the controversial [Babli
project](/wiki/Babli_project "Babli project") gates in Maharashtra was thought
to have affected the water flow in the river and water availability to the
[Sriram Sagar Project](/wiki/Sriram_Sagar_Project "Sriram Sagar Project")
except during above 20% excess monsoon (i.e. one out of four years) years.[41]

A study has found that the delta is at a greater risk as the rate of sediment
[aggradation](/wiki/Aggradation "Aggradation") (raising the level of the delta
through sediment deposition) no longer exceeds relative sea-level rise.[42] It
further states that the suspended sediment load at the delta has reduced from
150·2 million tons during 1970–1979 to 57·2 million tons by 2000–2006,[43]
which translates into a three-fold decline in the past 4 decades. Impacts of
this can be seen in destroyed villages like [Uppada](/wiki/Uppada "Uppada") in
Godavari delta,[44] destruction of Mangrove forests and fragmentation of
shoreline – possibly a fallout of dam construction.

Said to further epitomise the insensitivity towards Godavari, is the
[Polavaram Project](/wiki/Polavaram_Project "Polavaram Project") which is
touted to be gigantic – both in terms of size and violations.[45] Deemed as
being pointless and politically driven,[46] the project raises questions about
environmental clearance, displacement of upstream human habitations,[47] loss
of forest cover, technicalities in the dam design which are said to play down
flood threats and unsafe embankments.

[High alkalinity water](/wiki/Residual_sodium_carbonate_index "Residual sodium
carbonate index") is discharged from the ash dump areas of many coal fired
power stations into the river which further increases the
[alkalinity](/wiki/Alkalinity "Alkalinity") of the river water whose water is
naturally of high alkalinity since the river basin is draining vast area of
[basalt](/wiki/Basalt#Weathering "Basalt") formations.[48] This problem
aggravates during the lean flow months in entire river basin. Already the
Godavari basin area in Telangana is suffering from high alkalinity and
salinity water problem which is converting soils in to unproductive [sodic
alkali soils](/wiki/Alkali_soil "Alkali soil").[49] The following are the few
coal fired power stations located in the river basin:

Pollution concerns,  
River basin's sustainable  
productivity & ecology|

  * [Algal bloom](/wiki/Algal_bloom "Algal bloom") in reservoirs
  * [High alkalinity of river water](/wiki/Alkali_soil "Alkali soil") in the river basin upstream of [Pochampadu dam](/wiki/Sriram_Sagar_Project "Sriram Sagar Project")
  * Frequent floods in tail end area of the river basin
  * Alkali salts / high pH water run off from ash / [red mud](/wiki/Red_mud "Red mud") dumps of coal fired power stations / [bauxite](/wiki/Bauxite "Bauxite") ore enrichment
  * Excessive silting of reservoirs due to deforestation and mining activities
